text:
<@U05FZBDQ4RJ> I run a massive investigation with this.

• There is no option to delete a party. I tried to run `DELETE <https://participant-ibtc-devnet-1.console.dev.canton.ibtc.network/v2/parties/askdjfakjsf::1220fa8543db6c66fe3a55b1f180c8dfc7f876265c76684fbc1d35d89e02c8aafe8e>`  but got `405 Method Not Allowed` as response which is a clear indication that this is not an option.
• I tried to disable a party with the `participant.parties.disable(party)` . It run successfully so I guess it disabled the account, but I didn't see any effect on it. After I disabled it, I still could search it on the Admin UI, and there isn't any field which indicates whether it is disabled or not when I get it from chain. What Robert linked there is a Warning: `Disabling a party is not currently supported and is considered a dangerous operation.` so I assume it's not allowed to do right now.
• I deleted the canton user as well which is linked to the party. It didn't really care about it. Maybe it only removes the option to make a transfer on behalf of the user, but there is no clear indication that anything happened with the party. I still be able to list it on the Admin UI.
• Somehow I can de-authorize the party from the participant node. This means that the party no longer able to do anything on the participant so it won't be "local". But I did not find practical solution for that, so I assume it's not something what we can do on version 3.3.0.
Note: If I can list a party on the Admin UI, it means that it is still on-chain.

elements.text: I run a massive investigation with this.
There is no option to delete a party. I tried to run
as response which is a clear indication that this is not an option.
I tried to disable a party with the

. It run successfully so I guess it disabled the account, but I didn't see any effect on it. After I disabled it, I still could search it on the Admin UI, and there isn't any field which indicates whether it is disabled or not when I get it from chain. What Robert linked there is a Warning:
Disabling a party is not currently supported and is considered a dangerous operation.
so I assume it's not allowed to do right now.

I deleted the canton user as well which is linked to the party. It didn't really care about it. Maybe it only removes the option to make a transfer on behalf of the user, but there is no clear indication that anything happened with the party. I still be able to list it on the Admin UI.

Somehow I can de-authorize the party from the participant node. This means that the party no longer able to do anything on the participant so it won't be "local". But I did not find practical solution for that, so I assume it's not something what we can do on version 3.3.0.
Note: If I can list a party on the Admin UI, it means that it is still on-chain.

text: *Conclusion, we can't do anything about to delete them.*

elements.text: Conclusion, we can't do anything about to delete them.

Btw there is a field in the metadata, Disabled or Enabled or smth. That must toggle when you call disable? Its another question, where or whether that flag is handled anywhere else

text: In the end, it doesnt “help us”: if they see the party on the node, they might be suspicious we earn rewards (wrongly). If they know its only for transfers, they already know we arent :man-shrugging:

. If they know its only for transfers, they already know we arent

text: So i wouldnt bother

Sounds like some AI generated data got passed off as real data? Anyone know how that happened? It could have happened in one of our scripties on the eng side, perhaps even one of mine. It can sneakily make you think it’s doing code-driven actions, but actually it filled in imaginary data. Something to be wary of.

elements.text: Sounds like some AI generated data got passed off as real data? Anyone know how that happened? It could have happened in one of our scripties on the eng side, perhaps even one of mine. It can sneakily make you think it’s doing code-driven actions, but actually it filled in imaginary data. Something to be wary of.

text: <@U093Q4FPEJG> and <@U05FZBDQ4RJ> and <@U08Q9VCAM1A> and everyone, it sounds like there are quite a few little issues getting cleaned up. Just an idea, but consider just hopping on a call together to “war room” out some of these issues. Could be quicker than async.

text:
I suppose the customer PartyIDs should have come from the script typeform data? I’m not sure now how this data mistake got made. I’m curious though, AI is a tricky tool and we need to be accountable for our use of it.

It also crossed my mind that one of my scripts or perhaps Robert’s scripts to format the data and automate the creation of the parties could be the culprit as well. Perhaps what I thought was code to tweak data deterministically  was actually AI generating content, and it snuck by my radar.

I think it’s worth doing a bit of a “root cause analysis” on this, as this is the world we live in now, and AI will be getting sneakily into our data pipelines
